data.title: Option to prevent 'Untitled-1' when starting
data.body: Normally I don't need the untitled file when starting. If I want one, I can press <kbd>Ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>N</kbd>. It would be nice to have this as an option.

data.title: A subst drive is now ignored
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.0
- OS Version: Windows

Steps to Reproduce:
1. subst a drive (e.g. subst p: c:\users\xxxx\Projects)
2. open code from the subst drive

Observe: all paths shown in the UI are 'real' paths not the one from the subst drive.

data.title: Test: variable substition in launch.json and tasks.json
data.body:
- [x] any os @gregvanl 
- [x] any os @jrieken 

complexity: 3

We have consolidated our variable substition between debug and tasks into a `configurationResolverService` - #8754. Quickly verify:
- Simple variables get replaced inside `launch.json` and `tasks.json` as descirbed [here](http://code.visualstudio.com/docs/editor/tasks#_variable-substitution)
- You can reference environment variables inside your `launch.json` and `tasks.json` by using `${env.NAME}` syntax
- You can reference vscode settings inside your `launch.json` and `tasks.json` by using `${config.NAME}` syntax
- You can reference interactive variables inside your `launch.json` by using `${command.PickProcess}`

data.title: [emmet] Support for more languages
data.body:
Source: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/11329#issuecomment-247836884 and https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/11329#issuecomment-247863509
1. Remove hard code mapping for Handlebars (see [click](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/extensions/handlebars/package.json#L21)) & Razor (see [click](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/extensions/razor/package.json#L21)) after https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/pull/12039.
2. Remove old tests for Handlebars & Razor.
3. Remove extra `syntax !== thisLanguage` condition.
4. Add tests for languages that have different Language Id and scopeName.

data.title: Navigate to file and line in one command
data.body:
Actually the "omnibar" is able to navigate to a file or navigate to a line number, but it is not able to do both in a single action.

For example, if I want to open `test.js` and go to line `300`, the sequence is
1. CMD + P
2. `test.js`
3. Enter
4. CMD + P
5. `:300`

It would be really great if I could simply do
1. CMD + P
2. `test.js:300`
3. Enter

Done. I'm at `test.js` file at line 300.

data.title: Minor case change in README Github -> GitHub in README
data.body: Makes it consistent with the rest of the README.

data.title: Markdown syntax highlight breaks after '>' blockquote sign inside fenced code block
data.body: - VSCode Version: Code 1.5.2 (66f37fd2a99eb9d628dd374d81d78835b410c39b, 2016-09-12T13:05:12.065Z) - OS Version: Darwin x64 15.6.0 Steps to Reproduce: 1. Create a fenced code block that includes '>' in it. Example ``` class NewComponentController { static $inject: Array = [...]; } ``` 1. The highlighting breaks even after the end of the fenced code block. but it works okay in the preview and any other markdown editors.

data.title: Provide Symbols for CoffeeScript
data.body:
It seems like CoffeeScript support in Visual Studio Code is kind of limited to colorisation and it does not provide symbol navigation.

It should be fairly easy to add it using the coffee-script compiler and ask it to output nodes instead of compiled code.

Is that on your roadmap? If no, I'd like to try to add it out (I have a very basic working prototype, eventually)

data.title: Mac: Provide a setting to hide the title bar and inline the window controls

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Hello there, a lot of the standard apps in recent versions of macOS have started to inline their titlebar into their tabs, menu buttons etc. I assume this is mainly to save vertical space on laptops. However, like all UI trends, apps that don't quite keep up end up feeling old-fashioned ðŸ‘¯ 

I started a fork of VS Code that uses the inline style:

![screen shot 2016-09-21 at 12 59 09](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/49038/18710082/332cefb6-7ffb-11e6-8303-338bee1d6c35.png)

There needed to be a few changes:
- I moved the sidebar width to 76, to fit the traffic lights
- I increased the height of the elements that act as the titlebar by one pixel, mainly so that they align with the centre position of the titlebar items
- Allow mouse dragging via the sidebar, and the title elements

Fork: https://github.com/orta/vscode/tree/inline-titlebar
Changes: https://github.com/orta/vscode/compare/master...mac-titlebar-inline

I realise that VS Code is a cross-platform project, and so these changes should _probably_ only be applied in the context of macOS, which I'm happy to look into with some advice (I don't have a windows/linux machine to hand for example).  

I also know that no-one wants big unexpected UI changes on their OSS projects, so I've not made it as a PR, but I'd love to know if/what I can do to move this upstream?

_Sidenote:_ If someone can tell me how, I'm happy to make a downloadable build for people to try too, I couldn't find a way to do it - I'm still quite fresh to npm projects.

data.title: Intellisense
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.2
- OS Version: OS X 10.11.6

I'm trying to switch to vscode from another IDE.
I was wondering if it is possible to have an intellisense that do this:

if I have a variable called myVariable I would like to have it suggested if i enter just a few letters.. For example "mv" or "vbl" that are part of the variable name.
It looks like it only work for uppercase letter, so for example if the variable name is MyVariable and I enter MV it is correctly suggested.
I think it is related to case-sensitive settings, but I haven't found anything to change for this.
I appreciate any suggestions
Thx.

data.title: node-debug: Implement hit conditions for breakpoints
Implement Hit Condition UI for breakpoints
data.body:
`SourceBreakpoints` and `FunctionBreakpoints` support an optional `hitCondition` attribute which controls how many time a breakpoint has to be hit in order to 'break' execution.
Since a debug adapter is free to decide what kind of hit expressions to accept, the `hitCondition` is of type string.
This makes the attribute very similar to the already existing `condition` attribute of the breakpoint types and suggests that the UI for editing this new attribute aligns with the UI for editing breakpoint conditions.

The corresponding debug protocol addition:  https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-debugadapter-node/issues/37
And the implementation for node-debug: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/12374

data.title: Perf: renderer blocks when doing gulp watch and having many files open
data.body:
Steps to Reproduce:
1. have many files open (50+)
2. run gulp watch

=> close to the end when files are being written, the UI hangs
=> seems to be a large amount of deletes hitting our checks for disposing editor models if the associated file gets deleted

/cc @joaomoreno

data.title: Regex find within a file produces different results to `Find in Files`
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.2, Node: 5.10.0, Shell 0.37.6
- OS Version: Windows 7

It appears that `find in files` produces different results when using a regex search with new lines `\n` or lookbehind `?!`. See the screenshot below for an example. I would have expected `find in files` to return a result here. 

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/585546/18707646/f5a09e10-7fee-11e6-891c-d275e1eae72c.png)

I am aware that `find in files` will omit results if the result set is too large, that is fine and to mitigate this have have specified the directory, again see screenshot. 

**Steps to Reproduce:**
1. Ctrl+Shift+F to open find in files
2. Switch to regex mode
3. Enter a regex with a newline or lookbehind, there maybe others but these are the only ones I have encountered
4. Hit enter.

Depending on the regex you will either get a handful of results or non at all. However if you search in the file directly it will find all of the occurrences.

Cheers

Colin

data.title: Multiple filetype icon themes render side by side
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.2
- OS Version: Windows10 Pro

It's hard to reproduce but sometimes when switching icon themes, the old and the new icon theme render side by side.
It looks like the old icon theme get's cached somehow somewhere.

Steps to reproduce:
1. Download and set an icon theme. 
2. Close and reopen VSCode.
3. Go into FILE ICON THEME category and change to other icon pack theme.

I can reproduce the issue with `--disable-extensions` as well.

![icons](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1185797/18706050/07093018-7ff9-11e6-8c7b-ec2d26287353.gif)

![screenshot_327](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1185797/18705709/ee22b49e-7ff7-11e6-86b7-a682829af4ea.png)

![screenshot_328](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1185797/18706311/2e316e20-7ffa-11e6-95ae-2809491440be.png)

2.  Open terminal, type `ping 8.8.8.8 -t`, then press `Ctrl+C` to terminate the ping command

data.title: Typescript doc visible for aliased imports, but not for single ones.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.2
- OS Version: Windows 7 Service Pack 1
- Typescript version: 2.0.2

Steps to Reproduce:
1.  have a `myClass.ts` file exporting a `MyClass` class. Write some `/** */` doc for that class.
2.  In another file, try the following two ways of importing identifiers:

``` Typescript
import { MyClass } from 'myModule';
MyClass // When hovering MyClass, the written doc is not visible.
```

``` Typescript
import * as myModule from 'myModule';
myModule.MyClass // When hovering MyClass, the written doc appears.
```

It seems logical that the doc should appear in both cases, is this due to Typescript 2?

data.title: Keyboard bindings for code folding above level 5
data.body: Please allow code folding above level 5. I understand this is not something that is typically needed, but I see no obvious reason not to support it up to level 9 (keyboard shortcuts "ctrl+k ctrl+6" to "ctrl+k ctrl+9"). I actually need this now and it's a bummer to have to switch back and forth between VS Code and Notepad++ for this.
